ideas.title: Add visible focus ring styling to custom interactive card elements
ideas.description: Ensure ProjectCard, TaskBoardCard, and other custom interactive elements have consistent and visible focus indicators for keyboard navigation, following the Button component pattern.
ideas.rationale: While Button and Input components have proper focus-visible styles, custom interactive elements use 'focus:outline-none' which removes the default focus indicator without providing a custom one. This hurts keyboard accessibility and violates WCAG 2.4.7.
ideas.current_state: ProjectCard (line 112) has 'focus:outline-none' in className with no replacement focus style. TaskBoardCard (line 55) has 'focus:outline-none' on the card div. Both have tabIndex={0} and role='button' indicating they're keyboard accessible, but pressing Tab gives no visual indication of focus. Verified by grep - no 'focus-visible:ring' exists in these components.
ideas.proposed_change: 1. Update ProjectCard className (line 112) from 'cursor-pointer focus:outline-none' to 'cursor-pointer focus:outline-none focus-visible:ring-2 focus-visible:ring-ring focus-visible:ring-offset-2'. 2. Update TaskBoardCard className (line 55) similarly. 3. For cards with existing borders, consider 'focus-visible:border-primary focus-visible:ring-1 focus-visible:ring-primary/20' for a subtler effect. 4. Test keyboard navigation flow through all interactive elements to ensure focus is always visible.
ideas.user_benefit: Keyboard users can clearly see which element is currently focused, enabling effective navigation without a mouse. Essential for accessibility compliance (WCAG 2.4.7 Focus Visible).

ideas.title: Add tooltips to icon-only buttons throughout the app
ideas.description: Wrap icon-only buttons with Tooltip components to provide context about what each button does when hovering or focusing. Currently only 4 files use Tooltip (clients-content, sidebar.tsx, AvatarGroup, tooltip.tsx).
ideas.rationale: Many icon buttons across the UI (DotsThreeVertical menus, SidebarTrigger, action buttons, CaretUpDown workspace switch) lack tooltips, making them difficult to understand without clicking. Users encountering icon-only buttons need hover hints to understand functionality.
ideas.current_state: Grep shows only 4 files import Tooltip. Icon-only buttons like: CaretUpDown workspace switch (app-sidebar.tsx line 201-203), action buttons in ProjectHeaderActions (copy link, share, more), task drag handles (WorkstreamTab, TaskRowBase), and sidebar toggle have aria-labels for screen readers but no visual tooltips for sighted users.
ideas.proposed_change: 1. Import Tooltip, TooltipTrigger, TooltipContent from components/ui/tooltip.tsx. 2. Wrap icon buttons consistently: a) CaretUpDown (app-sidebar.tsx line 201) -> 'Switch workspace', b) ProjectHeaderActions buttons -> 'Copy link', 'Share', 'More actions', c) Drag handles -> 'Drag to reorder', d) Plus buttons -> 'Add new task/item'. 3. Set sideOffset={4} for proper spacing. 4. Ensure TooltipProvider is available in layout (already present in dashboard layout).
ideas.user_benefit: Users can discover functionality without clicking buttons. Reduces cognitive load and improves discoverability for both new and experienced users.

ideas.title: Add cross-platform keyboard shortcut display in sidebar search
ideas.description: The sidebar search button shows ⌘K which is Mac-specific. Add detection for Windows/Linux to show Ctrl+K instead, improving discoverability for non-Mac users.
ideas.rationale: The app supports both Mac (metaKey) and Windows/Linux (ctrlKey) keyboard shortcuts in the actual implementation (command-palette.tsx line 49), but the visual shortcut hint only shows the Mac variant. This creates confusion for Windows users who may not realize they can use Ctrl+K.
ideas.current_state: In app-sidebar.tsx (lines 217-219), the keyboard shortcut is hardcoded as: ...⌘K. Windows users see the Mac-specific ⌘ symbol. The CommandPalette component (line 49) correctly handles both metaKey and ctrlKey, but the visual hint doesn't match.
ideas.proposed_change: 1. Create a useIsMac() hook or inline check that detects platform: const isMac = typeof navigator !== 'undefined' && /Mac|iPod|iPhone|iPad/.test(navigator.platform). 2. Update app-sidebar.tsx kbd element to conditionally render: {isMac ? '⌘' : 'Ctrl+'}K. 3. Apply same pattern to CommandShortcut components in command-palette.tsx (lines 181, 188, 200, 205, 210, 216). 4. Consider creating a reusable KeyboardShortcut component that handles this automatically.
ideas.user_benefit: Windows and Linux users can immediately discover and use keyboard shortcuts without confusion, improving productivity and reducing the learning curve.

ideas.title: Add dark mode color variants to status badges in project cards
ideas.description: The statusConfig function in project-card.tsx uses light-mode-specific colors (e.g., 'bg-teal-50', 'text-teal-700') that may have poor contrast or appearance in dark mode.
ideas.rationale: The app fully supports dark mode via next-themes, but the status badge colors in project-card.tsx are hardcoded for light mode. This can result in low contrast text or jarring color combinations when dark mode is active, affecting readability and visual consistency.
ideas.current_state: In project-card.tsx (lines 21-35), statusConfig returns light-mode colors: 'text-teal-700 border-teal-200 bg-teal-50' for active, similar patterns for other statuses. No dark: variants are used. Compare to ClientStatusBadge in clients-content.tsx (lines 48-63) which properly uses dark mode variants like 'dark:bg-teal-500/15 dark:text-teal-100'.
ideas.proposed_change: 1. Update statusConfig in project-card.tsx to match the pattern from ClientStatusBadge in clients-content.tsx. 2. For 'active' status: change pill from 'text-teal-700 border-teal-200 bg-teal-50' to 'text-teal-700 border-teal-200 bg-teal-50 dark:bg-teal-500/15 dark:text-teal-100 dark:border-teal-500/30'. 3. Apply similar dark: variants to all status types (planned, backlog, completed, cancelled). 4. Also update the dot colors: 'bg-teal-600 dark:bg-teal-400' for better visibility.
ideas.user_benefit: Users in dark mode see properly styled status badges with good contrast and visual consistency, matching the polished look of other dark-mode-aware components in the app.

ideas.title: Enhance empty state designs with illustrations and actionable CTAs
ideas.description: Improve empty state messages throughout the app with larger icons, more descriptive text, and clear call-to-action buttons to make them more engaging and helpful.
ideas.rationale: Current empty states are minimal text messages (e.g., 'No tasks', 'No projects found', 'No active projects'). While functional, they miss an opportunity to guide users and make the empty state feel intentional rather than broken.
ideas.current_state: TaskBoardCard empty variant (lines 36-41) shows only 'No tasks' in a dashed box. project-board-view.tsx shows 'No projects found' in plain text. app-sidebar.tsx (line 273) shows 'No active projects' as muted text. These lack visual hierarchy, helpful guidance, or calls to action.
ideas.proposed_change: 1. Create a reusable EmptyState component with props for: icon (Phosphor icon), title, description, action (optional button with label and onClick). 2. Design: centered layout, icon at 48px with muted-foreground in subtle circular bg-muted/50 background, title in font-medium, description in text-muted-foreground text-sm, optional primary Button below. 3. Example for TaskBoardCard: <EmptyState icon={CheckSquare} title='No tasks scheduled' description='Tasks assigned to this day will appear here' />. 4. Example for sidebar: 'No active projects' -> 'Get started by creating your first project' with link to create.
ideas.user_benefit: Users understand that empty states are intentional (not errors), receive clear guidance on next steps, and experience a more polished, professional interface that encourages engagement.
